skills.name: Write a recurring decimal with a single digit recurring pattern as a fraction (US)

explanations.A: Not quite. Note that the line is only above the second digit, 1, not both digits. Also note that the line above the 1 means that the digit 1 repeats indefinitely, not just twice.
explanations.B: Nearly, but the line above the 1 means that the digit 1 repeats indefinitely, not just twice. Which answer represents that the digit 1 repeats indefinitely?
explanations.C: This would be correct if the line was above both digits, but it is only above the second digit, 1.
explanations.D: The line is above the second digit, 1, so it will be that digit that repeats and it repeats indefinitely: 0.51111111........

explanations.A: The line is above the second digit, 3, so it will be that digit that repeats and it repeats indefinitely: 0.733333........
explanations.B: This would be correct if the line was above both digits, but it is only above the second digit, 3.
explanations.C: Not quite. Note that the line is only above the second digit, 3, not both digits. Also note that the line above the 3 means that the digit 3 repeats indefinitely, not just twice.
explanations.D: Nearly, but the line above the 3 means that the digit 3 repeats indefinitely, not just twice. Which answer represents that the digit 3 repeats indefinitely?

explanations.A: This would be correct if the line was above both digits, but it is only above the second digit, 1.
explanations.B: Nearly, but after calculating 10 âœ• 0.4111... and 100 âœ• 0.4111... when you then subtract one equation from the other, ensure you carry out the subtraction on both sides of the equals sign.
explanations.D: This would be correct if the decimal was 0.41. But, that line above the digit 1 means that the digit 1 repeats indefinitely. Remember that you'll need to start by calculating 10 âœ• 0.4111... and 100 âœ• 0.4111... Then you can use these to work out an expression for 90 âœ• 0.4111... as the next stage.

explanations.A: Nearly, this is a correct fraction for 0.5777... but it is not the simplest form of the fraction.
explanations.B: This would be correct if the line was above both digits, but it is only above the second digit, 7.
explanations.C: This would be correct if the decimal was 0.57. But, that line above the digit 7 means that the digit 7 repeats indefinitely. Remember that you'll need to start by calculating 10 âœ• 0.5777... and 100 âœ• 0.5777... Then you can use these to work out an expression for 90 âœ• 0.5777... as the next stage.

explanations.A: This would be correct if the decimal was 0.25. But, that line above the digit 5 means that the digit 5 repeats indefinitely. Remember that you'll need to start by calculating 10 âœ• 0.2555... and 100 âœ• 0.2555... Then you can use these to work out an expression for 90 âœ• 0.2555... as the next stage.
explanations.B: 10 âœ• 0.2555... = 2.555... and 100 âœ• 0.2555... = 25.555... Subtracting one equation from the other, we get 90 âœ• 0.2555... = 25.555... âˆ’ 2.555... = 23. Therefore, 0.2555... = 23/90. And that is its simplest form.
explanations.C: This would be correct if the line was above both digits, but it is only above the second digit, 5.
explanations.D: Nearly, but after calculating 10 âœ• 0.2555... and 100 âœ• 0.2555 when you then subtract one equation from the other, ensure you carry out the subtraction on both sides of the equals sign.

explanations.A: Nearly, but after calculating 10 âœ• 0.3444... and 100 âœ• 0.3444... when you then subtract one equation from the other, ensure you carry out the subtraction on both sides of the equals sign.
explanations.B: This would be correct if the decimal was 0.34. But, that line above the digit 4 means that the digit 4 repeats indefinitely. Remember that you'll need to start by calculating 10 âœ• 0.3444... and 100 âœ• 0.3444... Then you can use these to work out an expression for 90 âœ• 0.3444... as the next stage.
explanations.C: 10 âœ• 0.3444... = 3.444... and 100 âœ• 0.3444... = 34.444... Subtracting one equation from the other, we get 90 âœ• 0.3444... = 34.444... âˆ’ 3.444... = 31. Therefore, 0.3444... = 31/90. And that is its simplest form.
explanations.D: This would be correct if the line was above both digits, but it is only above the second digit, 4.

explanations.A: This is a correct answer, but it is not in its lowest terms. What common factors do 15 and 90 have?
explanations.B: I think you've used the digits after the decimal point as the denominator, but this isn't how we convert a decimal to a fraction. To convert a recurring decimal, like this, to a fraction, remember that you'll need to start by calculating 10 âœ• 0.1666... and 100 âœ• 0.1666... Then you can use these to work out an expression for 90 âœ• 0.1666... as the next stage.
explanations.C: This would be correct if the decimal was 0.16. But, that line above the digit 6 means that the digit 6 repeats indefinitely. Remember that you'll need to start by calculating 10 âœ• 0.1666... and 100 âœ• 0.1666... Then you can use these to work out an expression for 90 âœ• 0.1666... as the next stage.
explanations.D: 10 âœ• 0.1666... = 1.666... and 100 âœ• 0.1666.... = 16.666.... Subtracting one equation from the other, we get 90 âœ• 0.1666.... = 16.666... âˆ’ 1.666... = 15. Therefore, 0.1666.... = 15/90 = 1/6. And that is its simplest form.

explanations.A: This would be correct if the decimal was 0.62. But, that line above the digit 2 means that the digit 2 repeats indefinitely. Remember that you'll need to start by calculating 10 âœ• 0.6222... and 100 âœ• 0.6222... Then you can use these to work out an expression for 90 âœ• 0.6222... as the next stage.
explanations.B: This is a correct answer, but it is not in its lowest terms. What common factors do 56 and 90 have?
explanations.C: 10 âœ• 0.6222... = 6.222... and 100 âœ• 0.6222.... = 62.222.... Subtracting one equation from the other, we get 90 âœ• 0.6222.... = 62.222... âˆ’ 6.222... = 56. Therefore, 0.6222.... = 56/90 = 28/45. And that is its simplest form.
explanations.D: I think you've used the digits after the decimal point to make the fraction 6/2 = 3. But this isn't how we convert a decimal to a fraction. To convert a recurring decimal, like this, to a fraction, remember that you'll need to start by calculating 10 âœ• 0.6222... and 100 âœ• 0.6222... Then you can use these to work out an expression for 90 âœ• 0.6222... as the next stage.
